I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  country  program  midterm  review  conducted  in  November  2005,  the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) from 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for establishment of the Clean Development Mechanism 
Fund (the CDM Fund) in the PRC.1 At the request of the Government, ADB sent a mission to 
the PRC to undertake reconnaissance about the CDM Fund from 18 to 20 January 2006. 
National  experts  were  engaged  as  staff  consultants  to  provide  a  background  analysis 
concerning the institutional structure and operational modalities of the proposed CDM Fund. A 
joint review meeting was held at ADB on 15–17 February 2006 between the Government, ADB 
and staff consultants to discuss the consultant report. Based on findings of the reconnaissance 
mission and staff consultants’ study, the ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC from 4 to 7 
April 2006 and reached agreement with the Government regarding the TA’s impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. 
The TA project design and monitoring framework is provided in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  PRC  signed  the  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate  Change 
(UNFCCC) in 1991, and ratified the Kyoto Protocol of the UNFCCC in 2002. As a developing 
participating country of the UNFCCC, the PRC is eligible to benefit from the Clean Development 
Mechanism (CDM) established under Kyoto Protocol; the validity of the CDM currently extends 
until  2012.  The  CDM  is  designed  to  promote  a  win-win  solution  between  developed  and 
developing countries in addressing global climate change. The CDM allows the developed 
countries listed in Annex I of the UNFCCC to fulfill their greenhouse gas (GHG) emission 
reduction obligations through investment or participation in GHG emission reduction projects in 
developing countries, where the costs for emission reduction are relatively low. By obtaining 
certified  emission  reduction  (CERs)  from  projects  located  in  developing  countries,  the 
developed  countries  can  meet  their  GHG  emission  reduction  targets  at  lower  cost,  while 
promoting sustainable development in developing countries.   
 
3.  It  is  estimated  that  the  PRC  could  implement  GHG  reduction  projects  that  would 
annually generate CER credits equal to 151 to 225 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent2. 
Based on an estimated $10 per million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent, this represents a 
potential annual CER revenue stream of $1.51 billion to $2.25 billion. According to a World 
Bank-sponsored study,3 the PRC has the potential to generate about 50% of the total worldwide 
annual CERs. These potential benefits need to be achieved through the CDM, by means of 
CER transactions between the project owners in the PRC and their counterparts from the 
developed countries. The Government regards the CDM as an important mechanism to (i) gain 
financial support and new technology from developed countries to complement its own efforts to 
promote sustainable development, and (ii) address climate change concerns on both a national 
and  global  basis.  The  Government  has  established  an  inter-ministerial  national  policy 
coordination group, headed by the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), to 
provide  oversight  for  policy  development  and  decision  making  on  climate  change-related 
activities.  
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 20 April 2006. 
2  ADB  Staff  Consultants.  February  2006.  Clean  Development  Fund  (CDF)  Consultants  Consolidated  Report,

4.  While recognizing the potential benefits the CDM can generate for the country, the 
Government has noted two general concerns related to CER transactions under the CDM: (i) 
certain CDM projects (e.g., hydrofluorocarbon [HFC] projects that are designed to capture and 
destroy  HFC  emissions  by  the  manufacturing  sector)  have  a  high  value  in  terms  of  CER 
revenues, but contribute less to sustainable development; and (ii) high CER market values 
could serve as a perverse incentive, stimulating operation of and further investment in polluting 
industries. To address these concerns, on 12 October 2005 the Government issued a decree, 
“Measures on Operation and Management of Clean Development Mechanism Projects” (Decree 
37). Decree 37 has introduced a levy on the CER revenues generated by various CDM projects 
in the PRC;4 the fees collected by the Government will be used to support domestic climate 
change-related activities. It also states that the Ministry of Finance (MOF) will develop, in 
consultation with the NDRC, detailed regulations and operational guidelines for collecting and 
using the resources mobilized through this levy.  
 
5.  In accordance with Decree 37, the Government will establish a specialized facility—the 
CDM Fund—to manage the fees collected from CDM projects. Furthermore, the CDM Fund may 
also  receive  technical  assistance  and  other  grant  support  from  external  funding  agencies, 
including ADB and the World Bank. These resources will be supplemented by donations and 
operational income. CDM Fund resources will be used to promote domestic CDM projects and 
other climate change-related mitigation and adaptation projects and activities, through provision 
of technical assistance, grant support, and loans. The CDM Fund will be operated under the 
guidance  of  a  governing  council  comprising  the  NDRC,  MOF,  Ministry  of  Science  and 
Technology, and Ministry of Foreign Affairs (the Governing Council).  
 
6.  The  levy  introduced  under  Decree  37  is  generally  welcomed  by  the  international 
community  as  an  innovation  to  further  enhance  the  rationale  and  integrity  of  CDM  as  a 
partnership  to  promote  sustainable  development.  The  World  Bank  has  agreed  to  support 
preparation of the CDM Fund by (i) providing staff consultants to prepare the draft operational 
strategy for the CDM Fund, and (ii) making available limited seed money through advance 
payment  for  CERs  purchased  under  its  Prototype  Carbon  Fund.  The  Government  has 
requested  TA  from  ADB  to  assist  in  designing  the  governance  structure  and  operational 
mechanism of the CDM Fund, in line with international experiences and best practices.   
 
7.  ADB has been providing ongoing support to the PRC for CDM capacity development 
and has implemented a number of early CDM projects. In 2002, ADB implemented TA 3840-
PRC: Opportunities for the Clean Development Mechanism in the Energy Sector.5 Under TA 
5972-REG:  Promotion  of  Renewable  Energy,  Energy  Efficiency  and  Greenhouse  Gas 
Abatement (PREGA), ADB prepared CDM documentation for six projects in the PRC. In 2005, 
the ADB CDM Facility successfully brokered the CER credits from Loan 2112-PRC Liaoning 
Environment Improvement Project. ADB also supported CDM development for Loan 2146-PRC 
Coalmine  Methane  Development  and  Loan  2032-PRC  Gansu  Clean  Energy  Development 
Projects. ADB is currently preparing the Carbon Market Initiative, which will provide innovative 
CDM financing for ADB-assisted projects. It is envisaged that the Carbon Market Initiative and 
the CDM Fund would complement each other in promoting CDM projects in the PRC. 
  
                                                 
4  According to Decree 37, the Government will collect 65% of revenues from the sale of CERs produced by HFC and 
perfluorocarbon (PFC) emission reduction projects, 30% from nitrous oxide (N O) projects and 2% from projects of 
2
national priority, including projects that focus on energy efficiency, new and renewable energy, the capture of coal 
mine and coal bed methane, and that support small scale reforestration.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be sustainable development in the PRC and support for 
international efforts to address climate change. Its outcome will be an increase in the number of 
CDM projects and other climate change-related mitigation and adaptation projects and activities 
in the PRC. The TA will help the Government establish the CDM Fund, with an appropriately 
designed  governance  structure  and  initial  operational  capacity,  in  further  pursuit  of  this 
development goal. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will assist the Government address key governance and operational concerns of 
the CDM Fund, through the following four major components: 
 
(i)  Component A: study and introduction of CDM fee collection mechanism. 
Under  this  component,  the  TA  will  provide  consulting  services  to  help  (a) 
examine the applicable accounting laws and principles and various government 
fee collection mechanisms; (b) propose operational alternatives for a CDM fee 
collection  mechanism  for  the  CDM  Fund;  (c)  prepare  the  draft  decree  or 
regulations,  as  applicable,  for  the  CDM  fee  collection  mechanism;  and  (d) 
conduct  consultation  with  stakeholders  as  part  of  a  participatory  consensus-
building process. 
  
(ii)  Component  B:  CDM  fund  governance  structure  and  capacity  building. 
Under this component, the TA will (a) design and establish the internal control 
and  governance  structure  of  the  CDM  Fund  (including  auditing  and  anti-
corruption  systems);  (b)  conduct  targeted  external  consultations  with  the 
UNFCCC Secretariat concerning registration procedures for CER transactions, 
and undertake a study tour to selected countries to visit potential CER buyers, 
and to gain an understanding of international experiences and best practices in 
the management of environment funds; (c) provide essential facilities, including a 
server and basic work stations, for a computer-based management information 
system for the CDM Fund; and (d) provide a training program for the staff of the 
CDM Fund and relevant local government officials.  
  
(iii)  Component C: CDM fund operations manual. Under this component, the TA 
will review the proposed operational strategy for the CDM Fund and prepare the 
manual guiding its day-to-day operation. 
 
(iv)  Component D: information dissemination and awareness program. Under 
this  component,  the  TA  will  organize  conferences  and  provide  support  for 
preparation  of  information  dissemination  and  public  awareness  materials, 
including a specialized website to promote awareness and support for climate 
change  activities  in  general,  and  to  promote  operation  of  the  CDM  Fund  in 
particular. 
 
10.  The major deliverables of the TA include (i) the draft decree and/or regulations on the 
CDM fee collection mechanism, (ii) a draft policy paper guiding the CDM Fund internal control 
and governance structure, (iii) a draft operations manual for the CDM Fund, (iv) a computer-

4   
based operational management information system, (v) training materials for capacity building, 
and (vi) materials (including a special website) for the information dissemination and public 
awareness program. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $800,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested that ADB finance $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s  TA  Funding  Program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  balance  of  the  TA  costs, 
equivalent to $200,000, through the provision of in-kind contributions in the form of office space 
and facilities and salaries of counterpart staff. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan 
are provided in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The MOF will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and has designated a senior official at 
the deputy director general level as the project director, who is responsible for daily decision 
making on behalf of the Government. The Governing Council (para. 5) will serve as the inter-
ministerial  steering  committee  to  provide  guidance  and  policy  coordination  support  for  TA 
implementation. The CDM Fund Preparation Office (CDMFPO), established by the MOF, will 
serve as the project management office for the TA. The CDMFPO has designated a senior 
official, with extensive operational experience in handling international projects, as the chief 
operation coordinator. They will supervise and coordinate all activities, including consulting 
services supported by the TA under different components.  
 
13.  The TA will provide 6 person-months of international consulting services in the areas of 
financial institution management (2 person-months) and fund management (4 person-months). 
The international consultants will be actively involved in developing the draft policy paper to 
design  the  governance  structure  and  internal  control  system  of  the  CDM  Fund  and  in 
formulating the draft operations manual. The TA will provide 24 person-months of national 
consulting services in the areas of project management (4 person-months), project financial 
management (4 person-months), PRC taxation law (3 person-months), taxation accounting (3 
person-months),  fund  management  (2  person-months),  corporate  management  (4  person-
months),  CDM  transactions  (2  person-months),  and  legal  counsel  (2  person-months).  The 
national consultants will be involved, to various extents and as appropriate, in implementing the 
four  major  TA  components  (para.  9).  All  the  consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  on  an 
individual  basis,  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  by  Asian 
Development Bank and Its Borrowers. Interdisciplinary cooperation and coordination among the 
consultants  will  be  managed  by  the  Executing  Agency  through  CDMFPO.  The  individual 
consultant selection and recruitment method is recommended because few consulting firms, 
international  or  national,  are  known  to  have  the  ability  to  organize  a  team  of  in-house 
professionals with such diversified expertise. Given the strong capacity of the Executing Agency 
and the designated project management office, a CDMFPO-led team of individually engaged 
consultants is considered the most efficient and effective arrangement for implementing the TA. 
Outline terms of reference for the consulting services are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
14.  The  TA  will  provide  the  necessary  hardware  (including  one  server  and  associated 
workstations for the CDM Fund Preparation Office), and related technical support for software 
development, to help the Government establish a computer-based management information 
system for the CDM Fund operation and launch a website-based information dissemination and

5
awareness program. The equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines and transferred to the Government upon completion of the TA.  
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 12 months beginning on 01 August 2006, 
with a scheduled completion date of 30 July 2007. Information on implementation progress and 
TA outputs will be disseminated through the TA information dissemination and awareness 
program, including the special website that is to be developed. The outcome of the TA will be 
subject to evaluation by both ADB and the Government, in accordance with their respective 
evaluation policies and requirements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Establishment of the Clean Development 
Mechanism Fund, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The TA activities will consist of four separate components to address governance and 
operational aspects of the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) Fund. The TA will require a total 
of  6  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  24  person-months  of  national 
consulting services. The components and associated consultant services comprise the following: 
 
(i)  Component A: Study and Introduction of the CDM Fee Collection Mechanism. 
This will require a total of 9 person-months of consultancy services, consisting of a 
national taxation legal specialist (3 person-months), national taxation accounting 
specialist (3 person-months), national CDM transaction specialist (1 person-month) 
and national fund management specialist (2 person-months).  
(ii)  Component B: CDM Fund Governance Structure and Capacity Building. This 
will require a total of 7 person-months of consultancy services, consisting of an 
international financial institution management specialist (2 person-months), national 
corporate management specialist (4 person-months), and national legal counsel (1 
person-month).  
(iii)  Component C: CDM Fund Operations Manual. This will require a total of 13 
person-months  of  consultancy  services,  consisting  of  an  international  fund 
management specialist (4 person-months), national legal counsel (1 person-month), 
national  project  management  specialist  (4  person-months),  and  national  project 
financial management specialist (4 person-months). 
(iv)  Component D: Information Dissemination and Awareness Program. This will 
require a total of 1 person-month of consultancy services, consisting of a national 
CDM transaction specialist (1 person-month). 
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
2.  Financial Institution Management Specialist (2 person-months). The financial institution 
management specialist will contribute to component B. The activities to be conducted include the 
following: 
  
(i)  Act  as  team  leader  to  coordinate  preparation  and  delivery  of  outputs  under 
component B, as directed by the Clean Development Mechanism Fund Preparation 
Office (CDMFPO). 
(ii)  Coordinate  preparation  of  the  CDM  Fund  internal  governance  policy  paper 
regarding internal fund control and governance structure. Prepare relevant technical 
sections of the policy paper relating to institutional management of the CDM Fund.  
(iii)  Provide input to the design of the international study tour and fund management 
training program.   
(iv)  Coordinate  preparation  of  fund  governance  guidelines  by  the  consulting  team, 
suitable  for  inclusion  into  the  CDM  Fund  operations  manual.  Prepare  relevant 
technical sections of the fund governance guidelines, incorporating international 
best management practices. The fund governance guidelines will include, but not be 
limited to the following: (a) relevant national laws and regulations, (b) financial 
management  procedures  for  fund  flows  through  CDM  Fund,  (c)  financial 
management procedures of the CDM Fund, (d) administrative management of the 
CDM Fund, and (e) audit and anti-corruption measures.  
(v)  Submit  the  draft  internal  governance  policy  paper  and  draft  fund  governance 
guidelines to the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the CDMFPO and the CDM Fund 
Governing Council for review; incorporate comments into final reports.

(i)  Act  as  team  leader  to  coordinate  preparation  and  delivery  of  outputs  under

(ii)  Coordinate  preparation  of  the  draft  CDM  Fund  operations  manual,  including

(iii)  Prepare relevant sections of the CDM Fund operations manual relating to aspects of 
fund management, as determined by the CDMFPO. Technical focus will include 
incorporation of international best practices in fund management into the operations 
manual.  
(iv)  Submit the draft CDM Fund operations manual to ADB and the CDMFPO for review 
and coordinate incorporation of comments. Submit the revised draft CDM Fund 
operations manual to the Governing Council for review; coordinate incorporation of 
comments into the final CDM Fund operations manual. 
 
B.   National Consultants  
 
4.  Taxation Legal Specialist (3 person-months). The national PRC taxation legal specialist 
will contribute to component A. The activities to be conducted include the following: 
 
(i)  Act  as  team  leader  to  coordinate  preparation  and  delivery  of  outputs  under 
component A, as directed by the CDMFPO. 
(ii)  Conduct  an  assessment  of  alternative  certified  emission  reduction  (CER)  fee 
collection mechanisms for the CDM Fund, particularly in relation to legal taxation 
aspects, including but not limited to the (a) legal framework for fee collection, (b) 
legal authority for a fee collection agency, (c) legal basis and options for enforcing 
compliance, and (d) legal basis for allocation of payment obligation.   
(iii)  Coordinate  stakeholder  consultation  meetings  to  obtain  views  of  relevant 
stakeholders. Stakeholders will include but not be limited to the Ministry of Finance, 
National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Ministry  of  Science  and 
Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, CER buyers and sellers and CDM projects, 
CDM operation-related consulting firms, and local financial bureaus.  
(iv)  Coordinate a consultation seminar with relevant stakeholders to obtain input into the 
fee collection options.  
(v)  Incorporate the stakeholders’ views into the CER fee collection options.  
(vi)  Prepare a report detailing the CER fee collection alternatives. Coordinate inputs 
from team members to the draft report. Present the draft report to ADB and the 
CDMFPO for review; incorporate comments.  
(vii)  Present the report to the Governing Council for review.

Appendix 3  11 
(viii)  Based on the response from the Governing Council, and in coordination with the 
CDMFPO, coordinate preparation of the draft decree or regulations (as applicable) 
for  implementation  of  the  preferred  CER  fee  collection  mechanism.  Allocate 
reporting responsibilities between team members, review technical inputs, compile 
reports and manage technical inputs from team members. Prepare relevant sections 
of the draft decree or regulations relating to legal issues.  
(ix)  The draft decree or regulations will include, but not be limited to, (a) the legal basis 
for the CER fee, (b) allocation of fee payment obligation, (c) accounting principles 
and  arrangements  for  CDM  revenue  and  the  CER  fee,  (d)  authority  and 
responsibilities  of  the  CER  fee  collection  agent,  (e)  financial  arrangements  for 
operational fee collection costs, (f) penalty for non-payment of the CER fee, (g) 
penalty for nonperformance of the fee collection agent, and (h) bookkeeping and 
auditing of the CER fund flow.  
(x)  Submit the draft decree or regulations to ADB, the CDMFPO and the Governing 
Council for review. Coordinate incorporation of the comments into the final draft 
decree or regulations 
(xi)  Prepare relevant sections of the operations guidelines, as directed by the CDMFPO, 
suitable for inclusion into the fee collection section of the CDM Fund operations 
manual. Allocate responsibilities and coordinate the preparation by team members 
of sections of the operations guidelines. 
 
5.  Taxation  Accounting  Specialist  (3  person-months).  The  national  taxation  accounting 
specialist will contribute to component A, and will conduct activities as directed by the team leader 
and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assess alternative CER fee collection mechanisms for the CDM Fund, particularly in 
relation to taxation accounting aspects, and including but not limited to (a) CER fee 
collection procedures, (b) bookkeeping and auditing procedures, (c) integration with 
existing taxation regulations and procedures, and (d) the framework for flow of CER 
fees.   
(ii)  Participate in stakeholder consultation meetings and consultation seminars to obtain 
views of relevant stakeholders, and incorporate these into the CER fee collection 
options. Stakeholder consultation will focus on accounting issues associated with 
the CDM fee collection mechanism.   
(iii)  Prepare relevant sections of the CER fee collection options draft report, focusing on 
accounting issues. Incorporate comments from ADB and the CDMFPO into the final 
report.   
(iv)  Prepare relevant sections of the draft decree or regulations for implementation of 
the preferred CER fee collection mechanism. Incorporate comments from ADB, the 
CDMFPO and the Governing Council into the final draft decree or regulations. 
(v)  Prepare relevant sections of the operations guidelines, suitable for inclusion into the 
fee collection section of the CDM Fund operations manual.  
 
6.  CDM Transaction Specialist (2 person-months). The national CDM transaction specialist 
will contribute to components A and D, and will conduct activities as directed by the team leader 
and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Component A. Assess alternative CER fee collection mechanisms for the CDM 
Fund, including but not limited to the CDM project cycle and CDM revenue stream.  
(ii)  Participate  in  stakeholder  consultation  meetings  and  consultation  seminars,  as 
directed by the team leader and CDMFPO, to obtain views of relevant stakeholders.

12   Appendix 3 
 
Stakeholder  consultation  will  focus  on  issues  relating  to  CDM  transactions. 
Incorporate the views of the stakeholders into the CER fee collection options.  
(iii)  Prepare relevant sections of the draft report on CER fee collection options, focusing 
on CDM transaction issues. Incorporate comments from ADB and the CDMFPO into 
the final report.   
(iv)  Prepare relevant sections of the draft decree or regulations for implementing the 
preferred CER fee collection mechanism. Incorporate comments from ADB, the 
CDMFPO and the Governing Council into the final draft decree or regulations. 
(v)  Prepare relevant sections of the operations guidelines, suitable for inclusion into the 
fee collection section of the CDM Fund operations manual.  
(vi)  Component  D.  Provide  technical  input,  as  required,  for  CDM  Fund  public 
dissemination activities. This will include, but not be limited to, provision of data for 
the CDM Fund website, brochures and publicity kits. The CDM specialist will also 
assist in preparing technical input for the initial newsletter. The scope of technical 
assistance required from the CDM specialist will be determined by the CDMFPO, as 
required to complete the public dissemination activities. 
 
7.  Fund  Management  Specialist  (2  person-months).  The  national  fund  management 
specialist will contribute to component A, and will conduct activities as directed by the team leader 
and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assess alternative CER fee collection mechanisms for the CDM Fund, including but 
not limited to operational fund management implications of alternative collection 
mechanisms and other issues relating to fund management.   
(ii)  Participate in stakeholder consultation meetings and consultation seminars to obtain 
views  of  relevant  stakeholders.  Stakeholder  consultation  will  focus  on  fund 
management issues. Incorporate the views of the stakeholders into the CER fee 
collection options.  
(iii)  Prepare relevant sections of the draft report on CER fee collection options, focusing 
on fund management issues. Incorporate comments from ADB and the CDMFPO 
into the final report.   
(iv)  Prepare relevant sections of the draft decree or regulations for implementation of 
the preferred CER fee collection mechanism. Incorporate comments from ADB, the 
CDMFPO and the Governing Council into the final draft decree or regulations. 
(v)  Prepare relevant sections for operations guidelines, suitable for inclusion into the 
fee collection section of the CDM Fund operations manual.  
 
8.  Corporate  Management  Specialist  (4  person-months).  The  national  corporate 
management specialist will contribute to component B, and will conduct activities as directed by the 
team leader and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare  relevant  sections  of  the  CDM  Fund  internal  governance  policy  paper 
relating to corporate management.  
(ii)  Assist the CDMFPO, as required, in the design and organization of the international 
study tour.  
(iii)  Design  the  fund  management  training  program  to  increase  fund  management 
capacity of CDM Fund staff and operational awareness of relevant government 
officials.  
(iv)  Prepare relevant sections of the fund governance guidelines suitable for inclusion 
into the CDM Fund operations manual.

Appendix 3  13 
(v)  Incorporate comments from ADB, the CDMFPO, and the Governing Council on draft 
reports into final documents.    
 
9.  Legal  Counsel  (2  person-months).  The  national  legal  counsel  will  contribute  to 
components B and C, and will conduct activities as directed by the team leader and the CDMFPO, 
including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Component B. Prepare relevant sections of the CDM Fund internal governance 
policy paper relating to legal issues.  
(ii)  Prepare relevant sections of the fund governance guidelines suitable for inclusion 
into the CDM Fund operations manual. Input will focus on legal issues associated 
with fund governance, as required.  
(iii)  Incorporate comments from ADB, the CDMFPO and the Governing Council on draft 
reports into the final documents.    
(iv)  Component  C. Prepare relevant sections of the CDM Fund operations manual 
relating to legal issues associated with the CDM Fund operations manual. Provide 
legal advice to the consultant team during preparation of the CDM Fund operations 
manual, to ensure the operations manual conforms with the existing PRC legal 
system.   
(v)  Finalize relevant sections of the draft CDM Fund operations manual by incorporating 
comments from ADB, CDMFPO and the Governing Council.  
 
10.  Project  Management  Specialist (4 person-months). The national project management 
specialist will contribute to component C, and will conduct activities as directed by the team leader 
and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare relevant sections of the CDM Fund operations manual, including but not 
limited to sections addressing: (a) proponent application procedures for CDM Fund 
resources; (b) procedures for approval of projects applying for CDM Fund support; 
(c) project implementation, supervision, and reporting requirements and procedures; 
(d) procurement and engagement of consultants; and (e) the CDM Fund internal 
project management mechanism.  
(ii)  Finalize  the  relevant  sections  of  the  draft  CDM  Fund  operations  manual  by 
incorporating comments from ADB, the CDMFPO and the the Governing Council.  
 
11.  Project  Financial  Management  Specialist  (4  person-months).  The  national  project 
financial management specialist will contribute to component C, and will conduct activities as 
directed by the team leader and the CDMFPO, including but not limited to the following: 
(i)  Prepare relevant sections of the CDM Fund operations manual including but not 
limited to: (a) eligibility criteria for CDM Fund support, (b) procedures for project 
evaluation and auditing, (c) project closure procedures, (d) financial management of 
CDM Fund resources, and (e) the CDM Fund internal financial management control 
mechanism.  
(ii)  Finalize  the  relevant  sections  of  the  draft  CDM  Fund  operations  manual  by 
incorporating comments from ADB, the CDMFPO and the Governing Council.
